claim: Germany and Austria are both part of the Eurozone

supporting.text: Germany adopted the euro as its official currency in 1999, replacing the Deutsche Mark, and is a founding member of the Eurozone.

attacks.text: Germany adopted the euro as its official currency in 1999, replacing the Deutsche Mark, and is a founding member of the Eurozone.
The claim mentions Austria, but A1 only provides evidence about Germany, leaving Austria's status unaddressed.
Austria also adopted the euro in 1999 and is a founding member of the Eurozone, similar to Germany.

supporting.text: Austria joined the Eurozone in 1999, replacing the Austrian schilling with the euro as its official currency.

attacks.text: Austria joined the Eurozone in 1999, replacing the Austrian schilling with the euro as its official currency.
The claim mentions Germany, but A2 only provides evidence about Austria, leaving the status of Germany unaddressed.
Germany is a founding member of the Eurozone, adopting the euro in 1999 alongside Austria, which supports the original claim.

supporting.text: Both Germany and Austria are listed as member states of the Eurozone by the European Central Bank and the European Union.

attacks.text: Both Germany and Austria are listed as member states of the Eurozone by the European Central Bank and the European Union.
The European Central Bank and the European Union may have outdated or incorrect listings, which could exclude or misrepresent member states.
The European Central Bank and the European Union maintain rigorous and up-to-date records, making errors in listings highly unlikely.
Germany and Austria could have opted out of certain Eurozone agreements, making their membership status ambiguous.
Germany and Austria have fully adopted the euro as their currency and comply with all Eurozone regulations, confirming their membership.

supporting.text: The euro is the sole legal tender in both Germany and Austria, used for all financial transactions within these countries.

attacks.text: The euro is the sole legal tender in both Germany and Austria, used for all financial transactions within these countries.
While the euro is the official currency, some businesses in border regions may unofficially accept other currencies like Swiss francs or US dollars.
Such unofficial acceptance is extremely rare and not legally binding, so it does not challenge the euro's status as sole legal tender.

supporting.text: Germany and Austria participate in the monetary policy decisions of the Eurozone through their representation in the European Central Bank.

attacks.text: Germany and Austria participate in the monetary policy decisions of the Eurozone through their representation in the European Central Bank.
Participation in monetary policy decisions does not necessarily mean full membership in the Eurozone, as non-Eurozone EU countries may also have some level of involvement.
Non-Eurozone EU countries do not have voting rights in the European Central Bank's Governing Council, which is a key distinction from full Eurozone members like Germany and Austria.
Some regions or territories of Eurozone countries may use other currencies or have special arrangements, which could complicate the claim.
Germany and Austria as sovereign states are fully integrated into the Eurozone, and any special arrangements in certain regions do not affect their overall membership status.

supporting.text: The treaties establishing the Eurozone, such as the Maastricht Treaty, were ratified by both Germany and Austria, binding them to its rules and regulations.

attacks.text: The treaties establishing the Eurozone, such as the Maastricht Treaty, were ratified by both Germany and Austria, binding them to its rules and regulations.
Ratification of treaties does not necessarily mean full compliance or continued membership, as seen with Greece's financial crisis and threats of Grexit.
Despite crises, no Eurozone member has legally exited, and the treaties remain binding unless formally renegotiated or revoked.
The Eurozone's legal framework allows for voluntary withdrawal under extreme circumstances, as outlined in Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union.
Article 50 applies to EU membership, not the Eurozone specifically, and no legal mechanism exists for unilateral Eurozone exit.
